finalPattern.statement: Titles that combine a first-person apology hook with strong negative sentiment toward a contemporary/‘new’ artist (e.g., “I’m Sorry…This New Artist Completely Sucks”) drive higher CTR and above-baseline TPS on Rick Beato’s channel by creating curiosity and polarization versus his usual neutral explainer titles.

data.statement: Titles that combine a first-person apology hook with strong negative sentiment toward a contemporary/‘new’ artist (e.g., “I’m Sorry…This New Artist Completely Sucks”) drive higher CTR and above-baseline TPS on Rick Beato’s channel by creating curiosity and polarization versus his usual neutral explainer titles.
data.reasoning: Rick Beato’s audience is primed for music analysis; a deviation into a direct, opinionated call-out of a ‘new artist’ is novel and provocative. The first-person apology (“I’m Sorry…”) plus ellipsis creates a curiosity gap, while negative valence (“sucks”) signals conflict, both known to increase clicks. This framing likely pulls in non-subscribers searching for the artist and boosts CTR; the controversy sustains watch time as viewers seek the justification. We can test by comparing performance of titles containing apology/negative terms (e.g., “I’m sorry”, “sucks”, “worst”, “hate”, “overrated”, “the problem with”, “ruined”) and “new artist/this artist” against channel baselines and inspecting CTR/retention.
